column4: type 'man mount'  at a terminal. If you managed to create partitions on it (using fdisk?), means kernel sees your flash drive, so it should be no problem. You'll need a special device, I'd guess (/dev/...) Also edit /etc/fstab according to the values you use to mount it manually. Hope this helps...

what command are you using? If it's a one-line, type it here...

the partition is setup as sdb1p1
try "mount -t ext2  /dev/sdb1p1 /my_flash" - "/my_flash_1" is an empty directory, change the name to something you like better
it tells me sdb1p1 does not exist
no should I reinsert flash drive?
oh, you have to create these devices. No need to touch your flash. Your problem is in /dev... You need to create that /dev/...
you have the /dev/MAKEDEV tool for that. Not sure I recall how to use it. I wonder if ubuntu has some tool to do the same. Anyone ??
yeah I could not even set the partition to ext2 yet
'ext2' is not a partivion. It's a partition 'type' used by linux filesystem.

googling for MAKEDEV would give you better help than I. At least you know where your problem is: not your flash, just configuring your linux. see http://linux.about.com/od/commands/l/blcmdl8_MAKEDEV.htm   for example.
